p.s: My hypothesis is, that Gatsby, who always acts like everything is under control, shows his real nature in this excerpt: A childish, nervous man, who is scared to lose Daisy again.
Jay Gatsby is, together with Nick, one of the two protagonists of The Great Gatsby, even though he does not narrate the story.
He was first mentioned by Jordan Baker (p. 16, l. 1), and is kind of mysterious.
Jay Gatsby is a man, who is about 30 years old.
He often appears, wearing a suit, talks in an elaborate way and picks his words with care (p. 50, ll. 6-10).
He is the neighbour of Nick and seems to be very rich and wealthy.
This you can see because he throws parties 2-3 times a week, has a huge mansion, a beautiful car, a pool and things like that.
No one knows, where all his money comes from.
He tells others, Nick too, that he is the son of some wealthy people in the middle-westMidwest (p. 64, ll. 31-32), who all died.
He also likes to tells, that he was educated in Oxford, was a hero in the war and travelled through Europe (p. 65-66).
Nick finds out that thatsthat's a lie.
There are some rumors about him too: Some say, that he killed a man once, others say, that he is a German spy.
Jay Gatsby also seems to be materialistic.
This you can see because he wants to give Nick some money to thank him, even though Nick wanted it to be a favour (p. 81).
He also seems to have everything planned out: The first meeting with Nick, the first reunion with Daisy, the talk in the car, where he wants to tell Nick about his past.
The most important thing about him is, that he is in love with Daisy, even though they have not seen each other in almost 5 years.
It is really important to him.
He threw all these parties only, so maybe Daisy would visit one of them one day.
In this excerpt thothough, he is nervous because, as he said, this is the first time meeting Daisy again, after almost five years (p. 85, ll. 15-17).
He breaks NicksNick's clock, walks outside in the rain, just to arrive after Daisy and there is always this weird silence.
Gatsby kind of acts like a child, which Nick tells him (p. 86, l. 8) because he is afraid, that anything could go wrong, nervous and a little bit unsure, if this was the right decision.
In the end of the excerpt he is very happy because everything went so well and he could finally show his house to Daisy.
The nervousness gets underlined, by that awkward silence, that appeared here and there.
Moreover the fact, that Nick, the only one of the three, who is not that nervous, is the narrator, makes it even worse.
In addition to that, the childishness of Gatsby is especially shown, when he ran after Nick, just to tell him, how terrible this situation was (p. 85, l. 26 - p. 86, l. 9).
His happynesshappiness shows, when he begins to smile because the sun was shining (p. 87, 20-22).
So in this excerpt there were bad and good moments.
Those were parted by Nick Carraway going outside, which underlines that contrast even more.
All in all I think Gatsby let his real emotions out and he was just a human in that moment.
Not a rich man, who has everything and everyone under control.
